The RIGHT home schooling can be much better than public schools. Most kids are little learning machines that are not really challenged to reach their potential in a public school. My daughter, disappointed at the public schools which seemed to be concentrating on taking mandated tests rather than teaching to potential, has switched to home schooling with good results. A certified teacher, she researched home school curricula, enrolled her children in private school designed to supplement home schooling two days a week where they learn social skills in a group atmosphere while taking classes in Latin, mathematics, music and others (third grade). The rest of the week the kids are taught on a regular schedule at home with an established curriculum and do their assigned homework from the private school. My daughter stays in touch with other home schoolers online to exchange experience. So far all are happy, testing far above grade level and are developing confidence and good work habits.
 It is no accident that we rank 25th in education among industrilized countries.

I would say the usefulness of home schooling depends on both your parenting ability and your school system. I do not believe that any home schooled individual could have recieved as good an education as I did going to public schools. This is because I don't think any single person really has all of the knowledge necessary to teach his or her children a variety of subjects, and an attentive student is going to learn far more from a series of qualified teachers. The problem is that too many students aren't attentive and don't care about their grades. If you, as a parent, can assure that your student cares about his or her grades and is going to pay attention and do his or her homework, then I'd recommed public school over home schooling in a second. 
 
 But I know a few people who made it through high school with a D average and couldn't solve "x/2 + 6 = 11" to save their lives. If you have trouble getting your child to take school seriously, home schooling might be a viable alternative, provided you are knowledgable in a variety of subjects and you are willing to allow your child to take a significant hit in the development of social skills. My recommended course of action would be: unless the school system in your area is notoriously worthless, send your child to public school, and if he or she starts doing poorly, speak with the school teachers to learn the topics being covered and combine public school with home education until your child takes education more seriously.

Do you thing it is better to be home schooled or learn at school?

 A public school alone is not adequate, nor is homeschooling alone. The bottom line is that homeschooling is not appropriate for someone who is not interested in learning or cannot learn by themselves. On the other hand, public schools offer poor environments (bad influences from you-know-what punks, gangs, druggies, etc.).
 
 Overall, I think homeschooling is the best _if_ it is complemented by interaction with other homeschoolers and people. Homeschooling without any outside or social interaction is degrading, because it's hard to get anywhere without basic social skills. I was homeschooled for a few years and did not benefit much from it. I really wasn't open to as many options as I thought I was. If a parent has a Ph.D. or knows a great deal about something, homeschooling would be beneficial academically.
 
 Private schools offer very good environments, but the course selections are usually very limited. The private school I attend essentially has course offerings for someone pursuing a B.A. in history. It doesn't offer any decent engineering, cs, or higher math courses. The science curriculum is absolutely pathetic, I might add. They have loads of AP History courses, but no consideration for an AP Science/Engineering course besides AP Chemistry. We have very many history and art classes, but no engineering, computer science, or even a decent IT course (they teach MS Word). What I will probably end up doing is independently studying AP Physics C, CS A, CS AB, and economics.
